author: By Chris Cameron and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Michigan State Suspends Football Coach Amid Sexual Harassment Allegations
description: Mel Tucker, the head coach, is accused of harassing Brenda Tracy, who speaks out against sexual violence in college sports, according to a report in USA Today.
content: Mel Tucker, the head football coach at Michigan State University, was suspended without pay on Sunday amid an investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct, university officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Flowers and Fake Marble: How TV Production Designers Create the Past
description: The people who designed the look of “The Buccaneers,” “The Gilded Age,” “Lessons in Chemistry” and “The Continental” discuss the importance of gilding, sledgehammers and eBay.
content: “I always say that if there were a marble Olympics, our team would definitely take the gold,” Bob Shaw bragged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Russia’s ‘Merchant of Death’ Is Looking to Forge a New Life in Politics
description: The convicted arms trafficker Viktor A. Bout hasn’t much flair for retail politicking, but his celebrity may compensate for that in regional elections.
content: As an arms trafficker, he operated in some of the world’s most dangerous places, becoming one of the world’s most wanted men and earning the nickname “Merchant of Death,” not to speak of a 25-year prison sentence in the U.S. But now, nine months after returning to Russia in a prisoner exchange, Viktor A. Bout is reinventing himself — as a local politician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 11, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Targets Ukraine’s Capital With Barrage of Drones
description: The attack, which Ukraine said it had foiled, is the latest in a campaign apparently intended to destroy infrastructure and demoralize the local population.
content: Ukraine’s military said on Sunday that it had foiled a large Russian drone attack on the capital, Kyiv, overnight, the latest barrage in a campaign intended partly to destroy military and energy infrastructure but also apparently aimed at terrorizing and demoralizing the local population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: The Half-Truth of America’s Past Greatness
description: Owning our country’s sins could bring understanding and forgiveness.
content: Many of us are familiar with “the talk.” I have in mind the African American version in which we outline for our kids how to engage with law enforcement. This is not an instruction on the nuances of legal rights. Instead, Black children receive tools to survive the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Aida Alami and Jenny Gross
title: In Quake-Battered Mountains, Many Moroccans Must Fend for Themselves
description: In a critical period for search-and-rescue teams, the Moroccan government has given few updates about its response and the scope of the destruction.
content: With debris and fallen rock blocking roads to Moroccan villages hit hardest by an earthquake, many residents began burying their dead and foraging for scarce supplies on Sunday as they waited for government aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Kitra Cahana
title: Salvation Mountain in California Searches for How to Save Itself
description: The folk art monument in the desert near the Salton Sea grapples with extreme weather, social-media-fueled tourism and its own tattering beauty.
content: In the summer, the desert surrounding the Salton Sea in California seems to glow from the glare of the unrelenting sun. The temperature can climb to 110 degrees and higher, and layers of dust coat car tires and the legs of people braving the heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Francis Kane
title: Millie Bobby Brown Writes About a Real-Life Wartime Mystery
description: In her debut novel, the British actor elaborates on a story told to her by her grandmother.
content: On the evening of Wednesday, March 3, 1943, 173 men, women and children lost their lives descending the steps — 19 of them — to an underground air raid shelter in East London. It was the largest civilian tragedy of the war and yet it was a mystery how it happened. There was no air raid that night, so why had the crowd panicked? Adding to the confusion: The victims were all wet; death in all cases was by asphyxiation; and there was only one broken bone. For two days, the government withheld information from the public, citing issues of security and low public morale. However, after all that East London had endured during the Blitz, to be blamed for panicking at this point was intolerable and unfair. The residents of Bethnal Green demanded an inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: More Than Gum and Coins Are Stuffed in These ‘Pockets’
description: In her nifty “Intimate History of How We Keep Things Close,” Hannah Carlson unbuttons the politics behind who gets to hide their belongings, and where.
content: This review of Hannah Carlson’s cultural study of pockets was grievously delayed. Why? Your critic lost her keys … again. No, they weren’t AirTagged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh and Nicholas Nehamas
title: At Iowa’s Biggest Game, Football and Politics Collide
description: Donald J. Trump and Ron DeSantis played off each other at the Iowa-Iowa State game, where the tables appeared to turn on the former president.
content: Two ardent rivals faced off on Saturday. Thousands of fans cheered and jeered from the sidelines. Tension and hope, celebration and outrage all around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Congress Embarks on Spending Battle as Shutdown Looms at End of September
description: The House returns this week with conservatives threatening both spending levels and Speaker Kevin McCarthy.
content: Congress is poised this week to dive into an epic fight over spending, as the Senate for the first time in years puts appropriations bills on the floor for debate and Speaker Kevin McCarthy tries to find his way out of a complex funding tangle that could ultimately threaten his leadership post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Wins the U.S. Open and a 24th Grand Slam Title
description: On a court where he had regularly played the villain, Djokovic soaked in the fan adoration as he beat Daniil Medvedev in straight sets.
content: Novak Djokovic has won so many Grand Slam singles titles in so many different ways, it is getting extremely difficult to keep track of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ariel Dorfman
title: I Watched a Democracy Die. I Don’t Want to Do It Again.
description: How Chileans remember the trauma of our past could not be more important than now, when the temptation of authoritarian rule is again on the rise.
content: For 50 years, I have been mourning the death of President Salvador Allende of Chile, who was overthrown in a coup the morning of Sept. 11, 1973. For 50 years, I have mourned his death and the many deaths that followed: the execution and disappearance of my friends and so many more unknown women and men whom I marched with through the streets of Santiago in defense of Mr. Allende and his unprecedented attempt to build a socialist society without bloodshed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: To Test the A.I. Learning Hype, I Visited Classrooms
description: Some tech proponents say generative artificial intelligence will revolutionize education. Yet, some schools are blocking it. Here was a chance for reporting.
content: In January, Marisa Shuman, a computer science teacher at the Young Women’s Leadership School of the Bronx, invited me to spend a few days embedded in her classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Katie Rogers
title: Biden Forges Deeper Ties With Vietnam as China’s Ambition Mounts
description: Visiting Hanoi, the president cemented a new strategic partnership that puts the memories of the past behind them and focuses on mutual concerns over Beijing’s assertiveness in the region.
content: President Biden cemented a new strategic relationship with Vietnam on Sunday, bringing two historical foes closer than they have ever been and putting the ghosts of the past behind them out of shared worry over China’s mounting ambitions in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Ambrose Akinmusire Learned to Let Go (With Help From Joni Mitchell)
description: The trumpeter will release “Owl Song,” a spare new album, this fall as he takes on a new role as artistic director of the Herbie Hancock Institute of Jazz.
content: For arguably the most technically gifted trumpeter of his generation, a lot of Ambrose Akinmusire’s breakthroughs actually come from letting go of standards and structures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Ukrainian Accounts of Torture Point to Systematic Russian Policy, Expert Says
description: The U.N. Special Rapporteur on torture said Moscow’s refusal to address the issue represented tacit approval of its use. Russia has denied it practices torture.
content: Torture perpetrated by Russian officers against Ukrainian civilians and prisoners of war has reached such a level that it is clearly a systematic, state-endorsed policy, a United Nations expert on torture said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Coco Gauff Says She’s ‘Ready’ for the Headiest Levels of Fame
description: Gauff, 19, has been in the spotlight since she was a 15-year-old playing Wimbledon, but after she won the U.S. Open singles title, those lights will burn far hotter.
content: The first thing Coco Gauff did after leaving the court in Arthur Ashe Stadium, with her first Grand Slam trophy in hand, was don a sponsor’s T-shirt proclaiming her as a champion. So it begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Wolfram and Campbell Robertson
title: Pennsylvania Fugitive Is Seen With New Look, Miles From Previous Search Area
description: After slipping through a perimeter, Danelo Cavalcante appeared clean shaven in an area 40 minutes away and obtained a van, which the police later found. He remains at large.
content: On Saturday morning, the fugitive who had escaped Chester County Prison and eluded authorities for more than a week was apparently surrounded, hemmed in by a sprawling law enforcement operation in the Philadelphia suburbs. But that night, the man showed up miles away, freshly shaven, in possession of a van and still very much at large.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ravi Mattu
title: An A.I. Leader Urges Regulation and a Rethink
description: The entrepreneur Mustafa Suleyman’s new book calls for lawmakers to seize the opportunities and mitigate the potentially catastrophic risks of artificial intelligence.
content: Mustafa Suleyman is one of the world’s leading artificial intelligence entrepreneurs, having co-founded not one but two start-ups at the cutting edge of the most transformative technology since the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Sophie Park
title: As Migrants Are Placed Around Massachusetts, Towns Are Welcoming but Worried
description: The mayor of Woburn, where hotels are housing 150 migrant families, said the state’s 40-year-old right-to-shelter law “was not meant to cover what we’re seeing now.”
content: Barely two weeks had passed since the migrant crisis arrived in their city of 40,000 people, 10 miles northwest of Boston, but the volunteers gathered at a church in Woburn on a recent evening sounded battle weary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: 11 Things You Forgot About the 2023 N.F.L. Season
description: After a busy off-season, Damar Hamlin is back, Odell Beckham Jr. is a Raven, Sean Payton leads the Broncos, and 10 players are out because of gambling violations.
content: The N.F.L. off-season has gotten shorter since the regular season was extended to 17 games, and it certainly feels shorter, too, given that once-mundane calendar entries, such as the start of off-season workouts, are now treated like red-carpet events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Ryan
title: For ‘Silver Tsunami’ With H.I.V., New Hope for Healthy Aging
description: A recent study showed that a statin drug significantly lowered the risk of heart attacks and strokes among middle-aged and older people with the virus.
content: Americans with H.I.V. are achieving the once unthinkable: a steady march into older age. But beginning around age 50, many people living with the virus face a host of health problems, from heart disease and diabetes to social isolation and cognitive decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Losing Sleep, but Not About Things on the Field
description: As Los Angeles raced to the top of the N.L. West yet again, six of the team’s players formed a bond by welcoming new babies into their families.
content: Brusdar Graterol, a right-handed reliever for the Los Angeles Dodgers, will always remember the day he saw his teammate Max Muncy sprinting straight toward one of the greatest moments of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Everyone or Everything
description: Hoang-Kim Vu raises our spirits.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: President Biden Keeps Hunter Close Despite the Political Peril
description: The possibility of a federal indictment of Hunter Biden stunned the president. Yet the bond between him and his only surviving son is ironclad.
content: Earlier this summer, President Biden was feeling hopeful.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 10, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 10, 2023.
content: An article on Page 52 about the gender gap in higher education misspells the name of a video game. It is Valorant, not Valarint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Families Cut Adrift by Concrete Crisis in U.K. Schools
description: More than 100 schools have had to shut or close areas off because of dangerous lightweight concrete, leaving many parents, especially those whose children have special needs, scrambling for care.
content: Helen Burness was working from home on Monday when the email arrived. In less than 24 hours, her 9-year-old daughter was set to return to school after the long summer break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: What Leotard Can Compare to This?
description: More than 100 designer costumes from the New York City Ballet are featured in a new book photographed by Pari Dukovic.
content: As a boy of 8, Pari Dukovic would pick up his camera, a gift from his father, and explore his native Istanbul. He learned to station himself on the street corners, hoping for just the right light to show off the city at its most shimmering. Soon enough, he was turning his lens on people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: For a Woman Bereaved in Quake, First Came Shock and Then a Wail.
description: More than 2,000 people were killed in the quake that hit Morocco on Friday night. Hardest hit was the province of Al Haouz, which is home to Amizmiz.
content: First came the news, then shock and then a scream. In the small town of Amizmiz in southern Morocco on Sunday, a woman let out a piercing cry as she absorbed the information that her two brothers had been killed in the devastating earthquake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Corruption Is an Existential Threat to Ukraine, and Ukrainians Know It
description: The fight against it amounts to a second front in Ukraine’s existential war against Russia.
content: President Biden talks of the world being divided into autocracies and democracies. But a more important division exists: between kleptocracies, where leaders treat their nations like personal piggy banks, and places where corruption is the exception rather than the rule.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Newest Green Space in Paris: An Overgrown Rail Line
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 10, 2023.
content: “If you want a true nature reserve, you can’t let humans in.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Hailed a Cab at My Hotel Near Central Park to Go to 47th Street’
description: A taxi makes an unplanned stop, a cozy flight to J.F.K. and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Gertner, Adrienne Hurst, Marion Lozano, John Woo, Daniel Ramirez and Andrea Vancura
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Wikipedia’s Moment of Truth’
description: Can the online encyclopedia help teach A.I. chatbots to get their facts right — without destroying itself in the process?
content: In early 2021, a Wikipedia editor peered into the future and saw what looked like a funnel cloud on the horizon: the rise of GPT-3, a precursor to the new chatbots from OpenAI. When this editor — a prolific Wikipedian who goes by the handle Barkeep49 on the site — gave the new technology a try, he could see that it was untrustworthy. The bot would readily mix fictional elements (a false name, a false academic citation) into otherwise factual and coherent answers. But he had no doubts about its potential. “I think A.I.’s day of writing a high-quality encyclopedia is coming sooner rather than later,” he wrote in “Death of Wikipedia,” an essay that he posted under his handle on Wikipedia itself. He speculated that a computerized model could, in time, displace his beloved website and its human editors, just as Wikipedia had supplanted the Encyclopaedia Britannica, which in 2012 announced it was discontinuing its print publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: Searching Morocco’s Quake Zone
description: Also, the technology tech giants refused to release.
content: Rescuers in Morocco struggled to reach remote areas in the mountains outside Marrakesh yesterday after the worst earthquake to hit the area in a century flattened homes across central and southern parts of the country on Friday. At least 2,122 people were killed and more than 2,421 were injured in the disaster, Moroccan state television reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Drew Lichtenberg
title: Shakespeare’s ‘Sublimely, Disturbingly Smutty Effect’ Must Endure
description: Shakespeare was interested in writing about the human experience — all of it — not denying or censoring these aspects of what makes us human.
content: When I wrote my recent essay on Shakespeare and cancel culture, I was not prepared for the overwhelming response of people flooding my inbox. Clearly, I’m far from alone in wanting my Shakespeare served straight, unpasteurized and unsanitized for polite and sensitive consumption. We lose something essential when we eradicate the sexual ribaldry, over-the-top violence, righteous anger and transgressive shock from Shakespeare’s work. It harms not only the rich texture of the plays but their meaning as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wolgelenter and Rachel Chaundler
title: Spain’s Top Soccer Official Resigns Over Unwanted World Cup Kiss
description: Pressure had been building on Luis Rubiales, with prosecutors opening an investigation, his soccer federation calling for him to step down and FIFA suspending him.
content: The head of the Spanish soccer federation, Luis Rubiales, resigned on Sunday, weeks after kissing a member of Spain’s women’s team on the lips after the team won the World Cup last month, setting off a national scandal and drawing accusations of abusing his power and perpetuating sexism in the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A Hacker, by Many Other Names
description: Someone with the distinction could be a prankster, a computer programmer or a “real lively” cutter of stone.
content: On Sept. 14, 1998, the reporter Amy Harmon covered a disturbance at her workplace: “A group calling for the release of Kevin Mitnick, the imprisoned computer criminal, commandeered The New York Times site,” she wrote. It was “the first time that hackers have penetrated the Web site of a major news organization.” (The website was secured later that day.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Official Held in Iran Prison in Brutal Conditions, Family Says
description: Relatives of Johan Floderus have released details of his incarceration since April 2022, revving up a public campaign on his birthday to bring him home.
content: Ten months with no communication with his family. Three hundred days in solitary confinement. A cell that’s fully lit around the clock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: Why ‘Girls’ Rule the Internet
description: Online, where people go on “hot girl walks” and make “girl dinner,” the word “girl” is more a mind-set than a statement about one’s age or gender.
content: Abi Balingit knows she’s an adult. She has a day job as an ad operations manager for a music company and a side job as a cookbook author. She pays the rent for her Brooklyn apartment every month and files her taxes every year. Also, she is 28 years old. But when she logs onto X, formerly known as Twitter, she becomes a girl or “girlie” — and so do the other women she talks to there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Covid Hero or ‘Lockdown Ron’? DeSantis and Trump Renew Pandemic Politics
description: The Florida governor has recently highlighted his state’s response to the coronavirus in hopes of striking some distance from Donald Trump.
content: Hank Miller, a 64-year-old Iowa farmer, started paying attention to Gov. Ron DeSantis during the coronavirus pandemic, when the Florida governor was a constant presence on Fox News highlighting the reopening of his state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Amid U.S. Open Fanfare, U.S.T.A. Fights Questions of Its Handling of Sexual Abuse
description: Kylie McKenzie accused a U.S.T.A. coach of inappropriately touching her when she was 19. In depositions, the organization has questioned her sexual history.
content: For several months, the United States Tennis Association has positioned this year’s U.S. Open as a key moment to celebrate its 50-year record of leadership on women’s equity and empowerment, tied to its payment of equal prize money to its top players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Alibaba’s Boss Steps Aside
description: Daniel Zhang, who had been expected to give up his chief executive and chairman roles this month, is also leaving as head of the company’s cloud division.
content: Daniel Zhang, the departing chief executive and chairman of the Chinese tech giant Alibaba, has stepped down as head of the tech company’s cloud division, a position he held for mere months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: At the U.S. Open, Coco Gauff and Company Stake Their Claim
description: Last year’s U.S. Open focused on goodbyes. This year, Gauff, the new singles champion, along with Ben Shelton, Frances Tiafoe and Taylor Fritz, burst through the front door with plans to stay.
content: Led by Coco Gauff and a cast of charismatic upstarts, tennis hit a sweet spot at this year’s U.S. Open with a diverse blend of old and right now, signaling the game is freshly and firmly energized as it enters a new era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Elon Musk’s Antisemitism Problem Isn’t About Free Speech
description: He hasn’t made X a “digital town square.” He’s made it his personal playpen.
content: Despite his loud and frequent protestations, Elon Musk may be the worst ambassador for free speech in America. To understand why, it’s necessary to look at X, the website formerly known as Twitter, which he owns and rules over like the generalissimo of a banana republic. The past several days are of particular relevance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Raboteau
title: How Our Roads Hurt Us and Everything Around Us
description: In “Crossings,” Ben Goldfarb shows that our dependence on highways and freeways is an environmental concern as well as a social one.
content: When my seventh grader walks to school from our home in the Bronx, he must cross the Henry Hudson Parkway (N.Y. 9A) over an ugly pedestrian bridge. To access the green space of Van Cortlandt Park a few blocks to the northeast, he must navigate an intimidating six lanes of traffic. I trust my kid to look both ways, but I don’t trust the drivers to notice him. I worry over the city’s roadways, the health consequences of their foul breath, their nonstop noise and the devastation they lay — by cruel intent — upon majority Black and brown neighborhoods like ours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Montei
title: Mothers Want to Be Left Alone
description: Motherhood shouldn’t require a loss of autonomy.
content: When my first child was a few months old, a man shouted at me while I stood in the snow with my sleeping baby slung over my shoulder, partially covered by a worn blanket. We lived in upstate New York, it was winter, and she had fallen asleep on me during a rare outing. As I impatiently waited for my husband to fetch our car, I must have looked disheveled there on the side of the road, trying to hold my baby up and keep her warm. “What kind of mother are you?” the man yelled out his car window. My arms went numb and hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karsten Moran
title: Seeing the U.S. Open in an Unusual Light
description: An infrared-converted camera gives a unique perspective on New York’s major tennis tournament.
content: The U.S. Open, which I have covered for five years for The New York Times, has no shortage of opportunities for staggering visuals. Especially on a sunny day, when the early afternoon light cuts crisp chiaroscuro shadows on the hardcourts, the players are easily transformed — their bodies contorted like ballet dancers and their faces transfigured by effort and focus as they emerge from deep shadow into brilliant sunshine to reach for a ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Plums Are in Season. It’s Time for Plum Torte.
description: Our most requested recipe of all time turns 40 this year, and it’s still going strong.
content: Good morning. It’s Emily again, and I’m thinking that today is a great day to make Marian Burros’s plum torte (above).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis Address Leniency Letters in Danny Masterson Rape Case
description: The letters to a judge ahead of Masterson’s sentencing described their friendship with him and spoke glowingly of his character.
content: Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher on Saturday spoke about letters they had written seeking leniency in the prison sentence of Danny Masterson, the actor best known for his role in the sitcom “That ’70s Show” who was found guilty of raping two women more than 20 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Atop the State Department, Democracy’s Treasures Can Complicate or Clarify Messages
description: The Diplomatic Reception Rooms house one of the finest art and design collections in the world. But are 18th-century heirlooms a history visitors want to remember — or forget?
content: In the 1960s, a distinguished guest showed up at the U.S. State Department and never left. It was the 18th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: New Mexico Governor Issues 30-Day Ban on Carrying Guns in Public in Albuquerque
description: The executive order, issued as a declaration of a public health emergency, comes after several recent shootings of children. Critics call the step unconstitutional.
content: Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham of New Mexico announced a 30-day ban on carrying firearms in public areas or state property in Albuquerque and its county, a move that she said was a necessary response to gun violence in the region but that critics denounced as unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Chinese Singer Denounced Over Video at Bombed-Out Ukrainian Theater
description: The singer Wang Fang drew criticism after she performed “Katyusha,” a Soviet-era patriotic song, at the ruins of a theater in Mariupol.
content: The Chinese singer stands on a balcony inside a bombed-out theater in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, the site of a deadly attack last year by Russian forces. Looking at the camera, she sings an excerpt from the Soviet-era patriotic song “Katyusha” and lifts her arms triumphantly into the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael R. Bloomberg
title: Michael Bloomberg: How Biden and Congress Should Fix the Immigration Crisis in Our Cities
description: The collapse of an orderly asylum process has left New York City struggling.
content: Our long-broken immigration system has now become a full-blown crisis with the collapse of the asylum process. The Biden administration has failed to address the steep price many cities are paying for a system they didn’t create and borders the cities don’t control. The White House ought to recognize the political damage the crisis will do to Democrats up and down the ticket in 2024 if it doesn’t take swift and decisive action.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Luring Theater Audiences Back After Covid
description: Readers discuss the decline in theater subscribers after the pandemic. Also: Northern Ireland; food allergies; a Covid playmate; anti-China bias.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
title: A Race to Rescue Survivors
description: Morocco’s worst earthquake in a century flattened homes and buildings, killing at least 2,000 people.
content: Rescuers in Morocco are racing to dig survivors out of rubble after the country’s worst earthquake in a century flattened homes and buildings, killing at least 2,000 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Marks and Vishakha Darbha
title: To Find Freedom, Gen Z Women Are Looking Back to Girlhood
description: Could a TikTok trend start a political movement?
content: This summer’s viral trend of “girl dinners” and “hot girl walks” felt like collective entertainment. For weeks, posts featuring women doing everyday activities — tagged with #girl — took over TikTok and Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Roz Chast Knows You’ll Always Regret Leaving the City for the Suburbs
description: “All of it: horrible,” says the beloved cartoonist. “Sorry.”
content: “All of it: horrible,” says the beloved cartoonist. “Sorry.”
source.name: The New York Times
